attributes.action: To create a tax incentive to favour retrofit instead of demolition and new build
attributes.background: To 0% rate VAT on refurbishment projects total costs if they substantially reduce CO2e emission of the building; impose a 20% VAT for new build schemes, reduced to 5% if the build meets minimum passive house standard; to 0% rate VAT for all items on a regularly updated list of energy-saving products
attributes.additional_details:
Since Brexit, UK has total freedom to use a differential VAT regime to address the climate emergency.
 
UK construction industry produces 40% of our total emissions; initial embodied carbon can account for 75% of lifetime emissions.  Retrofitting is carbon-efficient but the current VAT regime privileges new build over refurbishment.

The government could also incentivize retrofit by removing the liability for VAT from all energy-efficiency products and simplify the processing for claiming back.

attributes.action: Do not give consent to the Rampion2 windfarm extension off the coast of Sussex
attributes.background: Energy Companies should be encouraged to make investments in windfarms in areas like the North Sea where the winds blow at greater strengths and more constantly, resulting in higher efficiencies. This would also be out of sight of land.
attributes.additional_details: We believe the proposal to install up to 116 windturbines in Sussex Bay stretching from Worthing to Selsey will blight the whole seascape along this area of outstanding natural beauty. The turbines will be as tall as 325m, 2.35 times  the height of Rampion1 turbines, and  higher than any hill in West Sussex. Sited only 8 miles from the shoreline, this proposal will be much nearer land than many offshore wind farms, which will impact local communities to a greater extent.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Overhaul current, flawed EPCs so that they are fair, accurate & relevant.
attributes.background:
EPCs must
Recognise storage heaters are outdated and inflexible
Accurately reflect the energy efficiency of modern electric radiators
Recognise the Govt commitment to phasing out gas
Not make assumptions based just on age of property
Make realistic, achievable and cost effective recommendations
attributes.additional_details: Legislation based on flawed assessments is unfair & unlikely to achieve its aim. Under the current rating system it will be very difficult to improve a rating from an E to a C in many properties. Applying the legislation to the PRS without addressing the remaining housing stock is unfair and will result in many landlords dumping their inefficient properties into the Private Market, where improvements will be unlikely, thereby failing to achieve the Govt's aim.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Make it law for all new builds  to include green energy solutions.
attributes.background: Builders should be required to install green energy solutions in all new builds with immediate effect. For example, automatically installing solar panels on roofs of all new homes and business premises and thoroughly insulating new builds to save energy consumption.
attributes.additional_details: To reduce the use of fossil fuels, to increase energy efficiency and reduce the impact on the climate.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Remove VAT on Energy Efficiency Measures To Help Meet 2050 Emissions Target
attributes.background: Taxing people who voluntarily choose to upgrade the energy efficiency of their home goes against the government’s 2050 zero carbon target. Particularly as people building new homes that will ultimately add carbon emissions pay no VAT at all.
attributes.additional_details: Government signed the 2050 Net Zero emissions commitment into law in 2019 and that legislation has since been cited in the decision to prevent a third runway at Heathrow. While VAT on measures such as insulation and heat pumps has been reduced to 5%, it remains at 20% for items like LED lighting and Heat Recovery Ventilation, both of which are essential for a low carbon home. Zero-rating energy saving technologies would stimulate growth in the low carbon economy at a critical time for the UK.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Urgently review Advisory Electricity Rate (AER) for fully electric company cars
attributes.background: Since the energy price cap increase, domestic electricity costs ~28p/kWh. If a car’s efficiency is 2.8-4.0 miles/kWh, the cost per mile is 7p-10p. The average cost at a public charging point is 44.5p/kWh (~11p-16p per mile). HMRC’s AER is just 5p per mile. HMRC should urgently consider raising this.
attributes.additional_details: This shortfall discourages use of fully electric company cars. The Government should urgently review the current AER. It should also commit to reviewing the AER quarterly in future, as they do for fossil fuels in the Advisory Fuel Rates, and ensure the AER is not based on the lowest available domestic overnight tariff. For example, it would be fairer if the AER were set at the mid-point between the average of the cost of charging on a domestic tariff and on public rapid charging points.

attributes.action: Set minimum energy efficiency standards for retail fridges
attributes.background:
Supermarket refrigeration uses 1% of the UK's energy.
Inefficient fridge design leads to:
1) wasted energy
2) food spoilage and waste as temperature varies across the cabinet
3) increased plastic packaging to protect food that is kept at the wrong temperature
attributes.additional_details:
The world is under threat from the effects of global warming.

Legislating for improved fridge efficiency should help reduce our carbon footprint and prevent climate change.

Fridge doors may be useful, but can cause problems with hygiene (particularly since the covid-19 pandemic) and for people with mobility issues. Therefore the aim should be improving efficiency whilst maintaining the open design if possible.

I propose legislating for a target of 50% improvement in energy efficiency over the next 10 years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Do not give consent to the Rampion2 windfarm extension off the coast of Sussex
attributes.background: Energy companies should be encouraged to invest in windfarms out of sight of land such as the North Sea, enabling connection with the existing offshore grid network and keeping the impact to a minimum. Here stronger and more consistent winds should result in higher efficiencies than in the Channel.
attributes.additional_details: We believe the proposal to install up to 116 wind turbines in Sussex Bay stretching from Worthing to Selsey will blight the entire horizon along this area of outstanding natural beauty. The turbines will be as tall as 325m, 2.35 times the height of Rampion1 turbines, and higher than any hill in West Sussex. Sited only 8 miles from the shoreline, this proposal will be much nearer land than most offshore windfarms and will impact hard on local communities, the environment and the economy.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove VAT from energy-saving products
attributes.background: Remove VAT from energy saving products including insulation, energy-saving lightbulbs, smart heating technology and more. This should encourage households to be more energy efficient as we make the transition in the forthcoming years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Bring high percentage ethanol fuel to the UK
attributes.background: Follow the lead of European countries including Finland, France and Sweden, also America, Brazil and Australia, incentivise renewable ethanol biofuel to be made available at the fuel pump for the masses.
attributes.additional_details: Ethanol in fuels produce less carbon monoxide due to its more complete combustion and higher oxygen content. Incomplete combustion also creates hydrocarbons. Ethanol also produces less nitrogen oxide emissions which have a huge impact on the environment and humans. Ethanol creates less fine particulate matter which caused an estimated 200,000 premature deaths in 2014. Most engines can convert ethanols energy better and run better. While fuel consumption does go up energy efficiency also goes up.

attributes.action: Commit to cutting school carbon footprints to zero by 2025
attributes.background: The Government should pledge to cut schools' carbon footprints to zero. This could be achieved through the installation of air source heat pumps, solar panels on roofs, energy efficient lighting, better insulation and other energy efficiency measures.
attributes.additional_details: Achieving this would make schools a shining example and beacons for environmental change. Not only would the energy efficiencies count towards our UK carbon reduction targets but the message sent out to all pupils and students in schools would be that of positive change, and would surely spread throughout society. There are just under 25,000 schools in England. A Government pledge to drive schools towards carbon neutrality would be an investment fit for everyone's futures.

attributes.action: Fund a Lunar colony.
attributes.background: Fund and build one or more self-sustainable human outposts on the Earth's moon to act as a staging location for future colonisation of solar system as well as harvesters of Thorium and Helium-3 fuel sources which are abundant on the moon and can be used in Thorium (LFTR) and nuclear fusion reactors.
attributes.additional_details:
With climate change increasing the need for nuclear power as a primary energy source, this government is already investigating modern reactors which use Thorium to increase efficiency, and fusion and LFTR reactors, while still in the early stages of adoption offer greater gains which would justify this course of action in 50 years.

A more human justification is simply that this is the next logical step for our civilisation, and shows that we have faith in our collective futures in the universe.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Change building regulation, so house builders build more energy efficient home.
attributes.background:
I want the building regulation to change now, we are so behind our European friends in building efficiency, using renewable technologies.
Major house builders are building houses that have poor CO2 standards & have been getting away with it for years. Our old & new housing stock is very poor.
attributes.additional_details: Im a renewables technician, i see so many developments being built with a couple of PV panels on the roof(tick a box),  still installing oversized gas/oil boilers, not installing or thinking of future technologies like Heat Pumps. We want to reduce CO2, so why are major house builders not leading the way in this. Because the current regulations are at such a low standard, they dont have to. One major house builder still made profit of 296m pre tax profit in 2020.

rejection.details: We think this petition is similar to yours: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/332338

attributes.action: Remove the need for planning permission for energy efficiency improvements
attributes.background: We want the Government to amend planning legislation so that energy efficiency improvements, such as schemes to install double glazing and doors, including UPVC framed, do not require planning permission. Only grade 1 listed buildings should be excluded.
attributes.additional_details:
I live in a village which is partly a conservation area. The local council seems to systematically refuse planning permission for UPVC windows.
 
As a consequence of this we have many older buildings with windows in poor condition and which could be better insulated.
 
UPVC framed windows are much cheaper than wooden frames, require hardly any maintenance, and can appear very similar to wooden frames.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban the use of blue-rich lights for public lighting at night due to cancer risk
attributes.background: Owing to evidence that blue-rich lights used for some public lighting at night are associated with an elevated risk of prostate, breast and colorectal cancers, we believe that lights that are used for this purpose should be restricted to a correlated colour temperature of <3000K by law.
attributes.additional_details: Many street lights are being replaced with LEDs for energy efficiency reasons. Historically the most efficient LEDs had a high CCT value (4000K and over). Studies have shown that blue-rich lighting at night suppresses melatonin production, which can enhance the development of hormone-related cancers. The UK government should therefore mandate the use of low-CCT light sources for public lighting at night (<3000K) and require the replacement of any blue-rich sources within a reasonable time frame.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Do not put the clocks back this October and continue with British Summer Time.
attributes.background: I would like government to suspend daylight saving this year, ie vote to not put the clocks back in October.
attributes.additional_details:
The pandemic second wave is upon us and the mood of the whole country is low. Fewer people are commuting early to work because more are working from home.  Without the need to be up early it is more beneficial to have the light in the evening when most of population can enjoy it. 
With social distancing measures people will only be able to meet outside, so better lighting will make this easier and more energy efficient.
Light exposure may improve vitamin D levels leading to better immunity.

attributes.action: Provide global climate leadership by ending any new UK oil and gas extraction
attributes.background: Greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning are choking our planet and putting billions of people at immediate risk. But the UK Government plans to allow new oil and gas fields to start up between now and 2050. The UK Government must change policy and stop any new UK oil and gas extraction.
attributes.additional_details:
The viability of our societies depends on limiting global temperature rise to 1.5°C above the pre-industrial era average. It has already risen 1.1°C. 

Without deep carbon and methane pollution cuts (from burning fossil fuels) between now and 2030, the 1.5°C goal is unachievable. 

The UK Government must show global climate leadership by ending any new oil and gas extraction and announce support for a rapid expansion of renewable energy and a plan for increasing energy efficiency of UK homes.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/594797

attributes.action: The govt fully fund and undertake the insulation of all social housing by 2025
attributes.background: The govt immediately promise to enact within four months a legally binding national plan to fully fund and be responsible for full low-energy /carbon retrofit of all homes in Britain, with no externalised costs, by 2030 for a just transition to decarbonisation of all parts of society and the economy
attributes.additional_details:
To meet UK commitments under the Paris Agreement to stay below 1.5C and legal obligations under the Climate Change Act 2008, as amended in 2019, emissions from heating and powering homes must be reduced by 78% in less than 15 years and then to zero by 2050.
Nearly 15% of the UK's total emissions comes from heating homes. The CCC flag the "stalled" work, which 'must be viewed and supported by the Treasury as a national infrastructure priority" (2019) for energy efficiency, job investment & health

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see action to insulate homes in the UK, but we're not sure if you want this to apply to only social housing (referred to in your title) or all homes (referred to in the main text of your petition). In any case, the UK Government is only responsible for housing in England, and not Scotland or Wales.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Increase Environmental Protection and Green Focus in Covid-19 Recovery Plan
attributes.background: The government must enforce stronger environmental protection within plans for Covid-19 recovery. It must implement a green focus and invest in active travel, energy efficiency, renewable energy, nature tourism, wildlife and environmental conservation, and other green projects.
attributes.additional_details:
Despite declaring a climate emergency in 2019 the UK Covid-19 recovery plan has an overly strong focus on construction and development at the expense of protecting the natural environment.
Polls show a public preference for a change to the economy and a greener focus, which was promised but quickly forgotten. 
The UK has failed to meet the majority of climate action targets. 
It is our responsibility to protect the natural environment, especially after it has provided us with so many benefits.

attributes.action: All new buildings and home’s should be built with solar tiles on the roof
attributes.background: Change the building regulations.
attributes.additional_details: The technology is available to build houses with this type of tile. It seems like a great step towards more energy efficient buildings. With every roof that’s built, more electricity will be produced and more fossil fuels will be saved. The UK will be a little bit greener.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/584316

attributes.action: Introduce Carbon Tax to pay for Covid19 and transform to a green economy.
attributes.background: A Carbon Tax applied to products & services that release carbon dioxide in their production, use, or disposal. Things that might be low in Carbon Tax would be electric cars or local grown fruit & veg. Gas guzzling cars or processed meat products with plastic packaging would cost a little more.
attributes.additional_details:
The money generated from Carbon Tax would pay the COVID 19 debt mountain and transform to a green economy, revenue to be split 50/50. 

Measures implemented might be to encourage more home working to reduce commuting, which produces Carbon Dioxide, give everyone a free bike to encourage more cycling, give every house with a roof free solar panels and battery storage.  

A refurbishments & building programme of energy-efficient homes and infrastructure could be used to kick start the economy.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/321854

attributes.action: Improve the thermal performance of heritage buildings by changing the glass
attributes.background: I would like the Government to change the existing planning law to allow the use of Vacuum glass which will help reduce energy, prevent heat loss and reduce CO2 emissions.
attributes.additional_details: With global warming and the need to reduce CO2 emissions I want the Government to allow all homeowners the opportunity to change their existing single glazed windows and doors into thermally efficient windows and doors that will save the homeowner’s heating bills and in turn reduce energy costs which will also reduce CO2 emissions

rejection.details:
Under planning law listed building consent will normally be required where a listed building is to be altered in a way that effects its character as a building of special architectural or historic interest, but decisions about granting consent is a matter for individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

Historic England has published guidance on the care, repair and upgrading of traditional windows which states that “historic windows of interest should be retained wherever possible using careful matching repair" and that their complete replacement "should be a last resort and is rarely necessary” but, again, decisions about what alterations to grant consent for are a matter for individual planning authorities, not the Government or House of Commons.

attributes.action: Implement a green recovery package
attributes.background:
Invest in:
-Clean transportation
-Renewable energy 
-Retrofit buildings to improve their energy efficiency
-Reduce waste and improve recycling
-Protect nature and wildlife and restore degraded habitats.
attributes.additional_details:
This is essential as the recovery package can either bring us closer or further away from our zero-net emissions target. It can secure our and our children's wellbeing. It can build a competitive Britain in renewable energy and transportation or see us fall behind other nations.
The Committee on Climate Change illustrated that spending on low-carbon activities would provide a bigger boost to the economy, in both the short and long term, than pursuing a traditional recovery.

attributes.action: Make it law for all new builds to include green energy solutions.
attributes.background: Builders should be required to install green energy solutions in all new builds with immediate effect. For example, automatically installing solar panels on roofs of all new homes and business premises and thoroughly insulating new builds to save energy consumption.
attributes.additional_details: To reduce the use of fossil fuels, to increase energy efficiency and reduce the impact on the climate.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a similar action:

Require all new builds to have solar panels as condition of planning permission: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/617573

We could accept a petition calling for changes to planning rules regarding thermal insulation, but it would need to be clear what new requirements you wanted to be imposed.

attributes.action: More money invested into renewable energy sources
attributes.background: As a part of the 2008 Climate Change Act, the government must invest more money into renewable energy sources.
attributes.additional_details: The government isn’t putting enough money into their schemes. Included in the 2008 act is a pledge to reach net zero by 2050. This will simply not happen if the government doesn’t invest more money into increasing renewable energy sources, and support scientists in discovering how we can make these sources more efficient. This is why we are demanding significantly increased funding and investment, so that we can save our planet before it's too late.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/617729

attributes.action: Change listed buildings ancient laws to benefit homeowners
attributes.background: Review listed building policies to allow homeowners to update/insulate properties in keeping with surrounding areas, being respectful towards what is actually listed.
attributes.additional_details:
Review listed buildings laws, which are ancient and stopping owners of these properties making them energy efficient, more attractive to sell and buy whilst being respectful to what elements of the listed building applies.

In our case, a property converted on 1980’,s just a dorma porch and one side window of significant interest and the property is listed? It makes no sense.

7 dwellings are affected because of this ridiculous rule, stopping them from being efficient homes to own and maintain

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. We understand you'd like changes to the requirements for listed buildings, but we're not sure what you'd like to see change, such as removing the requirement for consent. 

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Impose sanctions on Russian oil and gas
attributes.background: UK sanctions against Russia and Belarus are not enough.  Oil and gas make up a fifth of Russia’s economy and half of its earnings from exports.  The UK needs to impose sanctions on Russian gas, and commit to cover the cost for low-income households in the UK.
attributes.additional_details:
Johnson promised sweeping sanctions to hobble the Russian economy.  Ukraine’s president Volodymyr Zelensky has called for stronger action.  This must be part of a long-term shift to renewable energy, energy efficiency and energy saving.

https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60503037
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-russia-what-you-need-know-right-now-2022-02-24/
https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/how-much-economic-pain-are-we-prepared-to-suffer-for-ukraine-xwsmfm5s0

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/609428

attributes.action: Remove Tfl Ulez compliant cameras in poor communities in South East London
attributes.background: Government approach to address air pollution in communities can not be generalised as communities differ in terms of their needs. I will enjoin Government to do the following in poor communities to address air pollution and improve quality of lives of the inhabitants.
attributes.additional_details:
1. A campaign that will encourage green building 
2. A campaign that will encourage people to ride a bike or walking instead of driving.
3. A campaign that will encourage taking a bus or carpooling. 
4. A campaign that will promote the use of energy efficient light bulbs and appliances. 
5. A campaign that will encourage people to turn 6. Government should focus on renewable fuel 
6.A campaign that will encourage people to buy fewer things that are manufactured using fossil fuels.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about the ULEZ and local advertising for public transport are a matter for Transport for London and the London Assembly, not the UK Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

The London Assembly has its own petitions process. You can find out more about how to petition the London Assembly here: https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to run national campaigns on some of the things you outline in your list.

attributes.action: Require all new-build supermarkets to be built with a living green roof
attributes.background: Government should introduce legislation requiring all new-build supermarkets to be built with a living green roof.  These help lower the supermarket’s carbon footprint, increase its energy efficiency, reduce surface run-off following rain and improve overall air quality for the community.
attributes.additional_details:
Air pollution is the biggest environmental cause of poor health. Up to 1,200 deaths each year in Greater Manchester are contributed to by poor air quality, which is likely to be increased by Covid-19. 
LIDL are proposing to build a new supermarket at Mocha Parade, Salford.  Two years ago they built a store in Malmesbury in Wiltshire with a living green roof.  Unless the government introduces legislation, LIDL and their competitors will not do the same in Salford or elsewhere.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/332338.
